docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, on Friday asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, to remove a special provision in the health care legislation that would have the federal government pay for all of Nebraska's costs of a proposed expansion of Medicaid, the federal-state insurance program for low-income Americans.

headline.main: Nelson Requests Removal of Nebraska Aid From Final Bill

docs.abstract: Senator Ben Nelson asks that proposed federal subsidies for Nebraska's Medicaid program be stripped from the final health care bill and that all states be given additional federal assistance to expand Medicaid programs.
docs.snippet: Senator Ben Nelson asks that proposed federal subsidies for Nebraska's Medicaid program be stripped from the final health care bill and that all states be given additional federal assistance to expand Medicaid programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: In virtually every industrialized country outside the United States, the contribution people make toward their health insurance is divorced from their age and health status. While this arrangement - known as community rating - is taken for granted abroad, it is still astoundingly controversial here in the United States.
docs.abstract: What if senators had to buy insurance as small companies do?
docs.snippet: What if senators had to buy insurance as small companies do?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Agenda is grateful to all the readers who shared their views about the House and Senate health care bills. It is striking to see, at least in the reaction to the second post, that the bills seem to be under even fire from the left and the right. Now, as Democrats in the Senate, House, and White House seem to be wrapping up their negotiations, we'd like to pick up on a couple of those points.

headline.main: On Health Care, Readers Speak; The Agenda Responds

docs.abstract: Please keep those cards and letters coming.
docs.snippet: Please keep those cards and letters coming.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated: President Obama will travel to Massachusetts on Sunday to campaign for the Democratic Senate candidate, Martha Coakley, the White House said, a sudden decision in response to growing concern that the party could lose its 60-vote majority in the Senate and a seat that for decades belonged to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline.main: Obama to Campaign in Massachusetts on Sunday

docs.abstract: President Obama will appear in Massachusetts to campaign for Senate candidate Martha Coakley.
docs.snippet: President Obama will appear in Massachusetts to campaign for Senate candidate Martha Coakley.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: Details of the agreement on taxing high-cost health insurance, a look at Google's early termination fee for its smartphones and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.
docs.snippet: Details of the agreement on taxing high-cost health insurance, a look at Google's early termination fee for its smartphones and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: White House and Congressional officials worked through Thursday night and into the wee hours of Friday as they continued to press for a final accord on far-reaching health care legislation.

headline.main: Wee-Hour Health Talks Focus on Costs

docs.abstract: White House and Congressional officials worked passed midnight as they press for a final accord on far-reaching health care legislation. One major challenge is controlling the bill's cost.
docs.snippet: White House and Congressional officials worked passed midnight as they press for a final accord on far-reaching health care legislation. One major challenge is controlling the bill's cost.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: Giving Senators the Health Plans Their Constituents Have

docs.abstract: Some politicians have argued for letting health plan premiums be based on an individual's health. An economist imagines the result if the Senate's own health plans operated this way.
docs.snippet: Some politicians have argued for letting health plan premiums be based on an individual's health. An economist imagines the result if the Senate's own health plans operated this way.

docs.lead_paragraph: The dust-up over the excise tax has been excised -- for now, at least.

headline.main: The Early Word: Health Tax Deal

docs.abstract: Democrats and union leaders seem to have reached a deal on a major roadblock: the proposed tax on high-cost insurance plans.
docs.snippet: Democrats and union leaders seem to have reached a deal on a major roadblock: the proposed tax on high-cost insurance plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the race is as tight as some polls suggest, Joe Kennedy could play a key role by drawing just a few percentage points from either of the other candidates.

headline.main: 3rd-Party Candidate Named Kennedy Could Tip Senate Race in Massachusetts
headline.print_headline: 3rd-Party Candidate Named Kennedy Could Tip Senate Race in Massachusetts

docs.snippet: If the race is as tight as some polls suggest, Joe Kennedy could play a key role by drawing just a few percentage points from either of the other candidates.

byline.contributor: Katie Zezima contributed reporting from Boston.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions said that they had reached agreement on a proposal to tax high-cost health insurance policies.

headline.main: Accord Reached on Insurance Tax for Costly Plans
headline.sub: White House, Labor and Congressional Leaders in Pact;
headline.print_headline: Accord Reached On Insurance Tax For Costly Plans

docs.snippet: The White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions said that they had reached agreement on a proposal to tax high-cost health insurance policies.
